author: adenan44
title: CARDANO HUB IN CKT
description: To facilitate the pace of Blockchain utilization, there is the need to obtain access in institution of higher learning.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal’s aim is to create a Cardano blockchain hub inside the CKT-UTAS, which is the Ghanian University of Technology & Applied Science, solving the allegedly no access in institutions of ‘higher learning’. 

This is an interesting focus and approach, since the all the students around the world are eager to create things and solve world problems. Having a university backing this knowledge will make the community grow and, moreover, will bring further development of Ghanian society in education area, firstly, and possibly in several other fields. Therefore, this proposal aligns with the challenge.

All the success/goals targets exposed align with the challenge. 

The continuation of this proposal after the money timeframe is possible since the statistics HOD is backing it. And I imagine that every semester has more students entering and graduating the university, therefore the hub will always be renovated and the continuation is easy.
f6_assessments.q1:
To facilitate the feasibility evaluation, we can divide this topic in some measures:
1 – Team: Since there are 2 WADA components and a CKT-UTAS professor, I imagine that the team won’t have any trouble accessing and having permissions to continue this project. It is possible to find the team members in the CKT-UTAS website (professor) and WADA org.
2 – roadmap: The presented roadmap is simple and it defines the weeks in which each task will take place, which seems sufficient.
3 – tasks: It could have some more information here. Exemplifying: there is a task of renovation of centre and setup. However, here we could use the information about why, in an UTAS university, there is a need to renovate the centre, or buy computers. Are there an intention to build a new lab instead of using the existing one and, if so, why? Another aspect that could be added are the topics to be addressed during the training sessions.
Therefore, adding these kinds of information could increase the transparency of the proposal. 
4 – budget:  There is a need to further explain some topics such as renovation of the hall (which renovation, what does it need?), miscellaneous, etc. Moreover, I think it must add a note explaining why there is no possibility to use an already existing lab in the university because the expenses to renew one and buy all the material accounts for more than 70% of the budget asked. That being said, I think it would be good to add some explanation note.
5 – Self fund/scalability: There was said that the proposer will return to the fund and gave no second plan of self-funding. However, there is a possibility to transform the hub into a  JEC (Junior Enterprise Concept), which is quite common in several countries in the world. It works as a enterprise which solves problems to other industries, enterprise, people, anyone, being directed by students (with a professor as mentor). The JEC charges for the services a value just for their maintenance (of course there is a profit, however it returns to the students in courses, e.g.). This might be a solution to funding and for scalability (other universities might copy the format).
6 – Risk management: It wasn’t stated any risk, however there is the scalability and continuity of the process (not necessarily it’ll be funded every round and, therefore, the continuation of this proposal might be affected). Implementing what was said in topic 5 might mitigate this risk.

That being said, it’s quite possible to implement this proposal, however it is missing some information that must be added.
f6_assessments.q2:
We can evaluate auditability by its:
1 – roadmap and milestones: The roadmap seems feasible, however it must be added some check points, allowing us to follow its progress. Like in the 1st month, there is no milestone or checkpoint, there are just some tasks to be completed.

2 – own channel: There was not presented any channel to share information. Maybe adding in the CKT-UTAS website or even create a separated one. 

3 – Metrics and KPI: All the metrics and KPI added evaluate the success of the proposal and always aligning with the challenge.

f6_assessments.q0: The project detailing does not address the challenge of growing Cardano in Africa.The objectives stated are to be a cardano hub and provide education and resources in the university of C.K Tedam in Ghana but this does not need much of a resource if the plan is to only educate people on how to use the blockchain.The college was founded in 2020 and the website shows 12 professors and less than 3000 students being graduated on 2020.This shows the exisisting infrastructure is not good enough to create any sort of network effects to attract students from other universities or even from their own.To begin with creating a hub for hackathons and resource materials they would need technically sound professors who are skilled and equipped enough of the underlying programming language utilised by Cardano in Haskell which clearly seems to not be the case here.The foundations on which this hub is being created adds even more to the worry as proper metrics regarding the existing infrastructure of education being provided is unavailable to assess for future growth metrics.The project is a long way or from being sustainable
f6_assessments.q1: The team mentioned here does not have any relevant exposure to Plutus or with being a professor related to depatrment of Computer Science.The majority of funds being requested seem to be to renovate halls and purchase basic equipments like Computers in the college,the lack of wherein is worrisome indicator of the existing unreliable infrastructure in place.No specifications in how would they create sources of training materials,hackathons and how they would create the learning materials even required in the first place and the timelines of developing them within the first month is another major red flag.The first thing to do would be to hire people with sufficient expertise and consult them on how to lay the frameworks and foundations for a longterm well articulated hub that would indeed enhance growth  and productivity.
f6_assessments.q2: The auditing of this seems to be manual and lacks for clear metrics and signs of progress and requires trust assumptions which could be faked upon pretty easily.No clear growth monitoring metrics and goals are provided henceforth the success of the project has no clear definition and requires trust assumptions which could potentially be manipulated. Who would be the educators and developers who are needed to be onboarded on the first place.The team could end up creating a cardano hub but with no clear vision and metrics to analyse the foundation remains bleak.

f6_assessments.q0: It does address the challenge effectively but i am wary of this proposal being able to offer what it says, at the funding cost requested.  a lot of budget is for computers, others are for learning materials which we have an abundance of on Cardano.  I dont see how this would be overtly beneficial.
f6_assessments.q1: Based on what this proposal is asking for, the areas it is concentrated in for funds (computers/education materials) seem superflous.  Again, there is a lot of material and there are a lot of resources that are available on chain or through cardano now, i dont see this proposal addressing anything new about the challenge; therefore i doubt implementation.
f6_assessments.q2: there are already funded projects that do this exact same mission and have been for several funds.  So while there is a possible way to audit, i feel it should be more concise and explicit when dealing with an area that has had a lot of funding and focus already. So while auditable, it seems lacking in auditability metrics.

f6_assessments.q0:
The idea of ​​the proposal has identified a part of the problem that needs to be solved for this challenge, but the scale of the impact of the project is huge, we can extend it to many different areas. conditions are the same around the world. Popularizing the use of Blockchain in educational and learning institutions is an issue that the founders of Blockchain companies are aiming for, it promotes society to approach Blockchain applications quickly.

The impact of this project is quite large, the solution of this proposed idea is great, it identifies almost every problem to be solved in this challenge, besides the author's argument through a description that is truly reasonable, clear, and complete. Having a continuing education center on the Cardano ecosystem within the CK Team University of Technology and Applied Sciences (CKT-UTAS) located in the Upper East Region of Ghana is a good solution, it serves as an illustration. Noting the development (though slow but steady) of Cardano in Africa in general, it is a place for students and researchers of Blockchain to have the opportunity to receive a lot of information from the industry as well as the benefits from Catalyst, from the Cardano ecosystem.

The description of this proposed idea does not measure the risks of implementation, I look forward to seeing the addition of risk management details in the next Fund if the concept is still alive. The introduction of Blockchain into a university for education will have the following primary risks:
_ Is it legally recognized in the host country? , as some countries are not yet fully open to Blockchain and Cardano.
_ What are the risks when operating a blockchain education center? solutions to reduce that risk.
_ Risk of personnel: there are enough members to jointly maintain the operation center? how long is the operation center expected? what is the effect it brings?
f6_assessments.q1:
This project provides clear and reasonable timelines for implementation and completion, compared with the information provided that this is completely feasible to implement, but the goals are not specific compared to the potential that the project brings. The goals that the project aims to need to be more detailed corresponding to the detailed timeline. For example, in the first week of completing the center renovation and setting up, the second week of completing the network infrastructure and setting up, etc. The more details, the easier it is for the community to check the project's implementation progress and direction to Cardano's self-governing stage.

The required project budget is less than 20% of the total funding budget of this challenge, compared to the information provided by the project, all expenditures for the project have been clarified, and explained very clearly and transparently.

Human resources to carry out this project have been assigned specific jobs for each item, the members' experiences show that it is completely suitable for the project, but the identity of the members is also difficult to verify. clearly. The author of this project, Adenankyage Awareweni Eric, with colleagues Professor Suleman Nasiru, and WADA member Baani Jeremiah, indicate that this is a team with experience implementing this project, however, the author please provide additional links to identify reputable identities such as LinkedIn, Facebook, Twitter, Discord, ... for the community to verify identity easily and practically.
f6_assessments.q2:
This project does provide KPIs to accomplish the project's goals, but some of the goals are difficult to measure compared to the information the project provides. The author please provide the effect when the center is put into use, for example, the number of Blockchain Ph.D. students expected to come here in a day and, what activities will be formed here, thus helping the community It is easy to imagine when this educational center will be put into use.

The ideas of this project have clearly defined success, however, they have not been tested in practice, but it is still a good idea. Completely new idea information on the Cardano platform, which has never received any funding from the Cardano ecosystem.

f6_assessments.q0: A problem within the challenge is the lack of hubs in Africa where people can learn and develop skills related to Cardano. The establishment of such a hub is indeed a way to promote and disseminate Cardano in the region. However, the hub proposed seems a little limited in terms of local impact and scalability. The KPIs defined in the end of the proposal marginally align with the challenge core ideas. The focus of the challenge is to spread the knowledge about Cardano and blockchain technologies to the general public and not only to a university universe niche. Apart from that I have not seen in the proposal any thoughts on reaching a self-sustaining target where they won't need project catalyst funding anymore.
f6_assessments.q1: The only link provided (http://www.ctiel.org/) to back the experience jotted down was not working when I tried to visit the site (checked on the 1st of July). Even though they haven't explicitly stated the number and type of members that will be required the three persons appointed in the “who is the team” section probably can take the tasks described in the previous section with the plan laid out. The budget, in turn, has been broken down into identifiable items but I have found some of the amounts a bit excessive. USD 1500 for snack and lunch of one ceremony for example is clearly disproportionate. The timetable, even though it sounds reasonable, is too shortsighted. There is no plan beyond the three-month threshold. Besides that, the proposers claim they are not aware of any risks. This makes it sound like a limited proposal. To make it more robust they could have discussed the challenges of not arousing enough interest in their hub or not being able to acquire all the setup they desired or even suffering from restrictions imposed by the university, for example.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer has provided a short-term roadmap (only 3 months) and the milestone described for month 3 sounds a bit generic. They claim they will "continue training" but do not mention number of people they intend to train, number of training sessions per week they are planning or even what will be the content of those sessions. The KPIs are defined in the "what does success look like" section instead of the "how to measure progress" section, but a part from that most of them make sense inside the idea of the proposal. As I have mentioned before they are focusing only on the impact inside the university which I find limited. Also, the last KPI, "stepping stone to other universities", is not well defined as it is extremely hard to measure that. All in all, even though the intention is good the solution does not seem to be very effective as the impact for Africa as a whole will be too narrow. Finally, they have not provided any public channel to keep the community up to date with their progress. I suggest they set up a social media account or a blog page for that.

f6_assessments.q0: The Cardano Hub in CKT proposal addresses the challenge objective of accelerating Cardano adoption in Africa well. By establishing the Cardano hub in CKT-UAS (a technology focused university in Ghana), the Cardano ecosystem in Africa can benefit from research, innovation and future events (hackathon) which will lead to increasing Cardano adoption in Africa. The proposal has a very good potential to scale in case it is implemented successfully and the other institutions of higher learning see it as a prototype to also partner with Cardano and introduce it to the wider audiences. Although the proposal hasn't mentioned about risk of completing the project, there could be some blockages in delivering the project. The examples of possible risks are its reliance on the collaborative efforts of many parties and also  declining in interest of students who are the major focus of Cardano adoption in this proposal. The proposal could be improved if the proposer would include possibility of such risks and how to tackle them in order to deliver this project successfully.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal has high potential to be implemented successfully as the proposer team members have reputation/ credibility from academic background and should be familiar with the process of setting up the blockchain center in the university. The proposal should have included their profile links that shows relevant skills and experience needed to carry out the project. The budget is reasonable and outlined clearly. Also the proposer could improve this proposal by listing the number of hours and pay rate/hour when it comes to variable cost items like production of teaching material, making brand paraphernalia and the key note speakers, etc. The timeline of 3 months are realistic to set the right basics for Cardano hub in CKT. The project roadmap and milestones are clear from the onset which tasks are required to bring this project to reality. It is possible that the proposer will seek future funding from Catalyst and it is recommended to be more specific in term of responsibilities of each team member (who is doing what) as this project size is relatively big and involves many parties. By assigning responsibilities to individual team member, it would be easier for following up in achieving the project KPIs and boost the impact of this proposal.
f6_assessments.q2: It is suffice to say that this proposal has provided enough background in roadmap, milestones and KPIs to audit the progress. The team aims to make this Cardano hub in CKT as a role model/stepping stone to other universities within the region and the success could be measured in term of number of students showing interest and getting involved with Cardano. It could take longer than 3 months as the project is comprised of many target groups (5 categories of Cardano fans   which need constant support and building rapport over time) to deliver the successful and long lasting impact to these groups. The proposer team understands the challenge brief well and has an effective solution to tackle the problem of Cardano adoption in Africa deploying education as the main strategy to increase future Cardano adoption. There are some other KPIs (in addition to the student numbers that the proposal could have listed as they expand their influence like number of partnership form, number of user sign-ups, etc.

f6_assessments.q0:
Cardano wants to spread its influence and user base to Africa, which is also the main reason behind this challenge. Best way for this to educate the people there about the blockchain and Cardano. This team’s proposal to create a hub for blockchain enthusiast to get together and share ideas is a great idea. Hubs are always positive environments for such purposes. This can really help to create a blockchain education center in this university. The proposal is also taking this one step further and plans to create some training materials and learning opportunities. Anyone working in this hub will also be working with Cardano and in turn may contribute to community.

The proposal does not list any risks for their idea. In any other proposal I would consider this as team is not taking the proposal seriously. However, when I think about it I cannot find any major risks either. This proposal is really risk free and directly related to challenge setting. This challenge can help this university and Ghana to become a leading force in Cardano adoption in coming years. After all with this proposal, many young students and blockchain enthusiasts can find an opportunity to learn more about Cardano. The team can help Cardano to get more African developers, more African projects, more Catalyst members, and also it can have major impact in the area.
f6_assessments.q1:
The planning is very solid and all the steps are given very clearly. Timelines are very realistic. Their purposes have been laid out to a reasonable timeline, and they have defined their milestones. Every item’s pricing in their budget is more than reasonable. They have thought this planning and budgeting very seriously and this can be seen in every aspect of the proposal. 

I would have loved to see more information about the team like; their main areas of expertises and interests, completed projects, and so on. I have checked if professor Suleman Nasiru has research papers about blockchain but there was none. If I understood correctly he will be helping the team about their communication with the University. With more time passes, he might also start to have more active role to incentivize other students. Other team members, Adenankyage and Baani, have more experience with blockchain technology and communities. I have checked their Twitter pages and also what WADA is working on at the moment, they are both very active in that community. Especially, I saw that Baani has already started to inform the young public in Northern Ghana in a program called ‘Mass Cardano Education’. Seeing such active people working to improve the lives of young people and contribute Cardano and Catalyst. One negative thing of the proposal here, they have given a link to website, ctiel.org, but the website is not working and they did not give any explanation for what that is.
f6_assessments.q2: Although there are some repeated thing in this part of the proposal and they have mentioned the expected outcome instead of progress tracking, the ideas here can be considered as tracking. Since the timeline for the project is only two months, progress will be short as well and I do not think it is a problem. I liked that all of the end goals are related to Cardano’s main goals in Africa. What they consider as success is also in line with Cardano’s views. This proposal can start a very useful movement first within Ghana then other countries. They are also planning to host Cardano team to their hub and this is also a great example to engage more and more students. I sincerely believe that this proposal should be funded and Catalyst should help this team’s ideas to spread to more people. If this proposal can be implemented without any problems, it can get attention from other universities or other countries. Which can be a great gateway for Cardano to reach more and more communities.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal seeks to establish a hub in a university in Northern Ghana. This is a brilliant idea because the northern parts of Ghana is a place that lags behind in developments of all forms and more especially digitization. This affects quality of life of most people especially the youth. First of all a Cardano hub will educate the students the use of blockchain technology and the Cardano ecosystem. Participation in the Cardano ecosystem and Project Catalyst can be a way gaining residual income to make their lives better. This is geared towards poverty alleviation. It will also fill the knowledge gap on digitization and blockchain technology. A number of youth stand to be onboarded as they get aware of the ecosystem. Moreover the idea to nurture Cardano ambassadors means the education goes on and on so this project will scale to solve future educational needs as like other hubs. 
There is also a higher probability of seeding innovative ideas from these students as they receive education.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposers have listed the number of team members needed for the project and their experience relevant to the execution of this project. That is a plus. But the Gail to give any link or attachments. 
The proposers have also listed all resources needed to successfully implement this project. There is a detailed budget of all listed items, activities and compensations that would be made. The funds requested is reasonable in my opinion taking into consideration the current cost of goods and services. 
The proposal presents a detailed plan with milestones and timelines that will help keep track of progress. Moreover the teams association with WADA which is a leading organization for Cardano ambassadorship in Africa. I think this proposal if funded will do well.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposers have given key milestones with timelines to help measure the progress of the proposal. The monthly milestones can help the proposers present reports to the community. The success metrics are also well outlined and they are simple and measurable. 
This proposal is auditable.

f6_assessments.q0: Educating the students of ck Tedam university on blockchain issues and the cardano blockchain is a good way to publicize cardano in Africa. This will bring cardano to spotlight in this university and also erase most misconceptions students have about blockchain issues. This idea is a brilliant thought and it closely aligns with the challenge . Establishing a hub in CKT will serve as an avenue for discussing blockchain issues, educating students about the opportunities available in the cardano blockchain and training students to put their innovative ideas into proposals to seek funding to implement those ideas to solve problems in their various societies in Africa. Training and educating these students will therefore means integrating them into the cardano community to contribute in roles like PAs, VPAs,proposers, referrers and many others. I believe this hub will help nurture cardano to grow wide in the northern regions in Ghana and other universities will see this as a motivation and a stepping stone to engage in the cardano blockchain. This project meets very well with what the challenge desires and will measure some of the key metrics of the challenge and for this reason,I suppose this proposal addresses the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
I will start with the experience of the team. Based on the description presented in the proposal,I am not soo convinced the author and the team has some level of experience in blockchain technology and are familiar with the cardano community and will be able to handle this project. The author should have supported his description with suitable and relevant links like their linkedins,twitter, Facebook and Instagram handles for us to get to know them much better and personally.i believe with these links,we will know how experienced and familiar they are with the cardano ecosystem. The only website (www.ctiel.org) provided cannot be found when searched for.
The budget is quite reasonable and it provided for everything that will be needed for the establishment of the hub. The items are clearly laid out and rational amounts portioned to them. Also,there is clarity in the timeline and clear milestones they hope to achieve. The team plans to use 3months in realizing this project and each month has it's well planned activities to take place. This is clear to us and I presume this proposal has the likelihood to be implemented.
f6_assessments.q2: Here,the proposer did not tell us how the community can audit the success of this project which I think the community should be able to monitor. I do not clearly comprehend how the expected outcomes listed in the proposal can be used to measure success,this is totally confusing to me. The key metrics in this proposal do not clearly indicate the number of students participating and I do not think this is a good way to measure success of the project and in essence, I do not believe this project can be audited safely and accurately. At least,we should be able to know,at the end of the project, the number of new members (students) expected to be onboarded,the number expected to contribute in roles in catalyst and also,we should be able to get monthly reports of the project but these are not indicated in the proposal and so I do not think the information presented to us is sufficient to audit the progress of this proposal.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal formulated the problem statement clear, but the formulation is not exactly as the a problem but rather as a solution.
"Cardano lacks representation in higher education institutions" would have been more in line with the request in the problem statement.
The proposal is aligned with the challenge statement, although some leaps of logic are needed, they are within common sense distance to not be considered a hindrance.
The positive impact on Cardano ecosystem could be more clear: there is no guarantee that the learning center will operate as intended.
Same with value added to Catalyst and Cardano: There is potential to add value, but no guarantee. I suggest the proposers collaborate with Catalyst governance research groups, such as QADAO, ADAO, Gimbalabs and SWARM to engage the learners to remain withing the ecosystem.
The KPI's are within what I would consider domain of the challenge.
The proposal seems to be able to scale in the future.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposers state relevant experience, and are affiliated with WADA, a Catalyst Community.
The budget is outlined clearly and is reasonable. The team composition seems reasonable to the best of my ability.
There is a detailed implementation plan.
The order of execution is clearly communicated,  The time line is realistic.
IMO The proposers should identify at least some feasible risks (at least there are risks to the being of the proposers themselves, we are all gods people, and there are always risks in the real world: the prices for the currency could fluctuate and prevent the fulfillment of the proposal, the prices for the equipment could change, there could be lack of interest from the students to learn about blockchain, students could learn on Cardano resources and go work at Solana)
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal provides a clear roadmap, the metrics make sense, but the looks like KPI and "what success looks like" were put in wrong order. 
The KPI"s could be more measurable (for example weekly class attendance, number of graduates, number of students who join the development, number of proposals posted and implemented by the graduates of the project.)

f6_assessments.q0: I think the overall idea is great, and with a clear focus on a University, implementation will be easier. However, I feel like I don't have enough information on how the project will achieve these goals, if there is a background study on-site with students to understand their interest in the subject, if there is already a designated physical space... There is also no defined risk, which can be dangerous for a project, as there are always risks. Some that could be mentioned is, for example, lack of interest from students, any bureaucracy from the University that could jeopardise the hub, etc. If the possible risks are well-thought, the proposers will be prepared if any of them come up.
f6_assessments.q1:
The roadmap feels a bit rushed, I am not sure renovations can be done in 1 month, and the hub would be ready for use in the second. In my opinion, this gives no margin for delays, which usually happens when there are renovations. The budget seems feasible, and I like how there is an amount dedicated to other expenses.
Regarding the proposers, they all seem to have the relevant experience, but I think there could be more information on their background, both professional and on Project Catalyst, with links for their LinkedIn or another website we could check their information.
f6_assessments.q2: I think the proposers chose goals that are very aligned with the challenge. However, I think the project could benefit from more defined and measurable KPIs, with an estimate of the number of people they intend to reach, for example, and how this will be measured. I think there could also be some deliverables to measure the project's progress, especially because the first month include mainly the preparation for the hub. For example, what does the project aim to achieve by the end of the first month Probably a physical space for the hub, but what are some of the characteristics of this physical space that would define what a successful hub is? All in all, while the set goals are valid, I think there could be some thought on the journey to these goals.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal did not clarify the problems it intends to solve.

Despite this, it was clear how the author wants to solve the problems he encountered. The objectives listed clearly demonstrate how they can add value to the ecosystem and achieve scale in the future. In addition, there appears to be a strong correlation with the objectives of the challenge.

A recommended improvement is to dedicate a small snippet to tell a little more about the specific problem. This will easily connect with the good framework of objectives that have been presented.
f6_assessments.q1:
Regarding the experience of the team involved, the author briefly indicated their academic titles. Unfortunately the institution's website appeared to be offline. It would be interesting to see links and other documents that tell more about the team's experience.

In the case of the action plan, relevant milestones were presented for the first three months, which help us understand how each step will be taken. In addition, the budget is well detailed and consistent with these steps.

A very important issue and good improvement to consider is the detailing of project risks, as no risk was indicated. In similar projects that I worked as a manager, I could observe risks related to financial issues, such as the maintenance of the program after its implementation, and related to stakeholder involvement, such as the possible low adherence of interested students.
f6_assessments.q2:
When asked about how the monitoring of the project development would be carried out, only expected outcomes were indicated. It would be important to understand, in fact, how the evolution of the project can be monitored.

The author indicated in the action plan section the milestones he intends to reach in the implementation of the project, which helps the community to understand the progress. In addition, he indicated good KPIs for us to understand that the results were achieved.

f6_assessments.q0:
I disagree ,taking into consideration the fact that the idea is quite confusing and am not very sure it aligns well with objective of this challenge, since the success of this challenge is aimed at a win win scenario for Africa and the Cardano ecosystems, but I didn't clearly understand per the information provided on how Africa gets its portion of the win.**************



 
 In as much as I think its a good idea, considering the University as Technology inclined, using i humbly suggest  the social media hub like zoom meetings etc will be ideal initially then as time goes on a hub can be thought of.*****************
Moreover I think some of the activities should be abit detailed to provide more clarification.
f6_assessments.q1:
I disagree this proposal is feasible, since information available to me concerning the team members relevant experience to execute this project are not clearly outlined..I suggest future proposals should have a link to their LinkedIn profiles as well, I humbly ask*******************************.
Moreover given the need to establish a hub in institutions of higher learning, I think detailed information on the budget was not carefully provided as in the cases of the prices of specific learning materials and well as information on what entails renovation of the hall. I will be much clear  in subsequent proposals if Detailed information of that sort is provided.
f6_assessments.q2:
I disagree, this proposal i think hasn't provided me with sufficient information to assess the progress against the stated goals.**************
The team is not able to provide me with direct KPIs  to monitor the project's success.
The team is unable to provide timelines to provide reports to the community on the state of progress of this project thus I doubt , with littlest confidence that activities can be timely measured

solution: CKT-UTAS is open to blockchain education. I seek to establish a hub in CKT-UTAS where different category of Cardano funs will be trained.
experience:
Professor Suleman Nasiru – Associate Professor of Statistics and Head of Department of Statistics
Adenankyage Awareweni Eric - Post Graduate Student (Blockchain educator and member of WADA)
Baani Jeremiah – (blockchain educator and member of WADA)
